title: Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy
icd10: ** G31.89 (Other specified degenerative diseases of nervous system)
F02.80 (Dementia in other diseases classified elsewhere
F02.81 (Dementia in other diseases classified elsewhere
scope: ** Clinical evaluation and management of suspected chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) and traumatic encephalopathy syndrome (TES), including application of 2023 NINDS consensus diagnostic criteria, biomarker evaluation (CSF, PET, MRI), differentiation from other neurodegenerative diseases (Alzheimer disease, frontotemporal dementia, Parkinson disease, dementia with Lewy bodies), symptomatic management of cognitive, behavioral, mood, and motor symptoms, and longitudinal monitoring. Definitive CTE diagnosis requires neuropathological confirmation — this plan addresses the clinical syndrome (TES) as defined by the 2021 NINDS/NIBIB consensus criteria. Applicable across ED (acute behavioral crisis, falls), Hospital (inpatient evaluation, behavioral management), Outpatient (primary diagnostic and management setting), and ICU (severe behavioral disturbance, aspiration, status epilepticus). Excludes acute concussion management, post-concussion syndrome (see separate plan), and pediatric populations.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Anemia worsens cognition and fatigue; infection screen
Electrolyte abnormalities, hepatic/renal function for medication dosing; hyponatremia can mimic cognitive decline
Hypothyroidism mimics cognitive slowing, depression, apathy; high prevalence in elderly
Deficiency causes cognitive impairment, mood changes, gait abnormality; reversible
Deficiency contributes to cognitive dysfunction; often comorbid with B12 deficiency
Neurosyphilis in differential for progressive dementia with behavioral features
UTI is a common cause of acute delirium/behavioral change superimposed on dementia
Substance use contributing to cognitive and behavioral symptoms; baseline
Alcohol intoxication or withdrawal mimicking or exacerbating CTE symptoms

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Inflammatory markers if autoimmune or inflammatory etiology suspected
Diabetes/metabolic syndrome contributes to cognitive decline; vascular risk factor
Vascular risk factor assessment; cerebrovascular disease exacerbates cognitive decline
If TSH abnormal; post-traumatic pituitary dysfunction
Post-traumatic hypogonadism contributing to mood, cognition, fatigue
Hepatic encephalopathy in differential if liver disease suspected
If on seizure medications; subtherapeutic levels may contribute to seizures

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Differentiate CTE from Alzheimer disease; CTE shows normal or mildly abnormal A-beta with elevated p-tau
Rare/Specialized.target: CTE: normal A-beta 42; AD: low A-beta 42, high p-tau 181

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Biomarker of neurodegeneration and axonal injury; elevated in active CTE
If rapid progression raises concern for prion disease (CJD)
APOE-e4 allele associated with worse outcomes after TBI and possibly CTE progression
If clinical suspicion for hypopituitarism (fatigue, weight gain, hyponatremia) years after TBI
If subacute presentation with prominent psychiatric features; rule out autoimmune etiology
Environmental/occupational exposure contributing to cognitive symptoms
If rapidly progressive course raises concern for paraneoplastic neurodegeneration

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate if acute presentation with new symptoms, fall, behavioral crisis, or focal deficit
Essential/First-line.target: Rule out hemorrhage, mass, hydrocephalus, subdural hematoma (common in CTE patients due to falls and brain atrophy)

Essential/First-line.timing: Within 2-4 weeks in outpatient; sooner if progressive or new symptoms
Essential/First-line.target: Disproportionate frontal/temporal atrophy, cavum septum pellucidum, corpus callosum thinning, hippocampal atrophy; rule out mass, NPH, vascular disease

Essential/First-line.timing: 3-6 months after initial evaluation; required for TES diagnosis
Essential/First-line.target: Pattern: executive dysfunction, memory impairment (retrieval > encoding), impulsivity; distinguish from AD pattern
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Patient cooperation required; acute psychiatric distress

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast
Extended.timing: If progressive symptoms, new focal deficits, or concern for mass/inflammation
Extended.target: Rule out enhancing lesion, inflammation, metastatic disease
Regional volume loss patterns: medial temporal, frontal, thalamic

Extended.timing: If diagnostic uncertainty between CTE, AD, FTD
Extended.target: CTE: frontal and temporal hypometabolism; AD: temporoparietal; FTD: frontal predominant

Extended.timing: Differentiate from Alzheimer disease; amyloid-negative dementia favors CTE/FTD
Extended.target: Negative amyloid PET favors CTE or FTD over AD

Extended.timing: Research; emerging role in detecting tau patterns in vivo; CTE tau has different distribution than AD
Extended.target: CTE pattern: sulcal depth tau deposition (research) vs AD: temporoparietal

Extended.timing: If seizures suspected; post-traumatic epilepsy risk
Extended.target: Rule out epileptiform activity; diffuse slowing in advanced CTE

Extended.timing: If excessive daytime sleepiness, sleep fragmentation, suspected sleep apnea
Extended.target: Identify obstructive sleep apnea (common comorbidity worsening cognition)

Rare/Specialized.target: White matter tract disruption, reduced fractional anisotropy

Rare/Specialized.timing: If PET not available; less specific
Detect prior microhemorrhages from repetitive trauma
If parkinsonian features; differentiate from idiopathic PD, DLB

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.indication: Acute agitation, psychosis, severe behavioral disturbance in CTE

dosing.instructions: 2-5 mg IV/IM q30min PRN; max 20 mg/day; use lowest effective dose

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.contraindications: QT prolongation, Parkinson disease, DLB (severe sensitivity), neuroleptic malignant syndrome history
Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.monitoring: QTc monitoring; EPS; sedation level; neuroleptic malignant syndrome signs

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.indication: Acute agitation when oral not possible; less EPS than haloperidol

dosing.instructions: 5-10 mg IM; may repeat in 2h; max 20 mg/day

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.contraindications: DLB (avoid); concurrent benzodiazepine IM (respiratory depression); uncontrolled diabetes

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.indication: Acute agitation with anxiety; adjunct to antipsychotics; seizure prophylaxis

dosing.instructions: 0.5-2 mg q4-6h PRN; max 6 mg/day; avoid chronic use

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.contraindications: Severe respiratory depression, acute narrow-angle glaucoma, myasthenia gravis
Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.monitoring: Respiratory status, sedation, paradoxical agitation (elderly); fall risk

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.indication: Post-traumatic seizures; seizure management in CTE

dosing.instructions: 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; may increase to 1500 mg BID; max 3000 mg/day

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.monitoring: Behavioral side effects (irritability, aggression); renal function; suicidality

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.indication: Status epilepticus or refractory seizures in CTE patient

dosing.instructions: 20-40 mg/kg IV load (max 3000 mg) at 3-6 mg/kg/min; then 500 mg IV q12h; target level 50-100 mcg/mL

Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.contraindications: Hepatic disease, pancreatitis, urea cycle disorder, pregnancy (teratogenic)
Acute/Emergent (Behavioral Crisis and Sa.monitoring: Valproic acid level, LFTs, CBC, ammonia, platelets

Cognitive Symptom Management.indication: Cognitive impairment in CTE/TES (memory, attention); cholinesterase inhibitor

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily; increase to 10 mg daily after 4-6 weeks; max 23 mg daily

Cognitive Symptom Management.contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome, AV block, active peptic ulcer, severe bradycardia
Cognitive Symptom Management.monitoring: HR (bradycardia); GI effects (nausea, diarrhea); vivid dreams; weight loss

Cognitive Symptom Management.indication: Cognitive impairment with comorbid parkinsonian features; alternative to donepezil

dosing.instructions: PO: Start 1.5 mg BID, increase by 1.5 mg/dose q2wk, max 6 mg BID; Patch: start 4.6 mg/24h, increase q4wk to 9.5 then 13.3 mg/24h

Cognitive Symptom Management.contraindications: Sick sinus syndrome, AV block, active peptic ulcer, severe bradycardia
Cognitive Symptom Management.monitoring: HR; GI effects; application site reactions (patch); weight loss

Cognitive Symptom Management.indication: Moderate-to-severe cognitive impairment; NMDA receptor antagonist; adjunct to cholinesterase inhibitor

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily; increase by 5 mg/week; target 10 mg BID; max 28 mg/day (XR)

Cognitive Symptom Management.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust if CrCl <30); concurrent use of other NMDA antagonists

Cognitive Symptom Management.indication: Cognitive fatigue, processing speed deficits, attention impairment in CTE

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO BID (morning and noon); increase by 5 mg/dose every 3-7 days; target 10-20 mg BID; max 60 mg/day; avoid afternoon dosing

Cognitive Symptom Management.contraindications: Uncontrolled HTN, cardiac arrhythmia, glaucoma, anxiety disorder (relative), substance abuse history
Cognitive Symptom Management.monitoring: HR, BP; appetite, weight, sleep; anxiety; potential for abuse

Cognitive Symptom Management.indication: Cognitive fatigue, apathy, processing speed; dopaminergic support

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg PO every morning; increase to 100 mg BID after 1 week; max 200 mg BID; avoid evening dosing

Cognitive Symptom Management.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose adjust), seizure history (relative), uncontrolled CHF
Cognitive Symptom Management.monitoring: Livedo reticularis, ankle edema, hallucinations, insomnia; renal function

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg PO daily; increase by 25 mg every 1-2 weeks; target 50-150 mg daily; max 200 mg/day

Behavioral and Mood Management.monitoring: Suicidality monitoring (weeks 1-4); GI upset; sexual dysfunction; serotonin syndrome; hyponatremia (SIADH in elderly)

Behavioral and Mood Management.indication: Depression, anxiety in CTE/TES; better tolerated in elderly

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO daily; increase to 10 mg after 1-2 weeks; max 20 mg daily (10 mg in elderly)

Behavioral and Mood Management.monitoring: Suicidality monitoring; QTc; hyponatremia (elderly); sexual dysfunction

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg PO daily; increase to 20 mg daily after 1-2 weeks; max 20 mg/day in elderly (QT risk)

Behavioral and Mood Management.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs, QT prolongation, congenital long QT
Behavioral and Mood Management.monitoring: QTc monitoring (max 20 mg in >60 years); hyponatremia; suicidality monitoring

Behavioral and Mood Management.indication: Agitation, irritability, insomnia in CTE/TES (dual benefit)

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg PO QHS; may titrate to 100-150 mg QHS for sleep; for agitation: 25-50 mg BID-TID; max 300 mg/day

Behavioral and Mood Management.monitoring: Orthostatic hypotension; priapism (rare); morning sedation; fall risk in elderly

Behavioral and Mood Management.indication: Agitation, psychosis, sleep disturbance in CTE/TES; low EPS risk

dosing.instructions: Start 12.5-25 mg PO QHS; increase by 25 mg every 2-3 days; target 50-200 mg/day; max 300 mg/day

Behavioral and Mood Management.contraindications: DLB (use with extreme caution); uncontrolled diabetes; QT prolongation
Behavioral and Mood Management.monitoring: BLACK BOX: increased mortality in elderly with dementia; metabolic effects (glucose, lipids, weight); QTc; EPS; sedation

dosing.instructions: Start 20/10 mg PO daily x 7 days; increase to 20/10 mg BID; max 20/10 mg BID

Behavioral and Mood Management.contraindications: Concurrent MAOIs, quinidine hypersensitivity, concurrent quinidine/quinine/mefloquine; prolonged QT
Behavioral and Mood Management.monitoring: QTc; hepatic function; dizziness; serotonin syndrome risk with SSRIs

Behavioral and Mood Management.indication: Impulsivity, aggression, mood instability in CTE (mood stabilizer)

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg PO BID; increase by 200 mg/week; target 400-800 mg/day; therapeutic level 4-12 mcg/mL

Behavioral and Mood Management.contraindications: HLA-B*1502 positive (SJS risk in Asian descent), AV block, bone marrow suppression, hepatic porphyria
Behavioral and Mood Management.monitoring: Drug level; CBC (agranulocytosis); LFTs; sodium (hyponatremia); HLA-B*1502 screening before initiation

Behavioral and Mood Management.indication: Aggression, impulsivity, mood instability; also seizure prophylaxis

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg PO BID; increase by 250 mg every 3-5 days; target level 50-100 mcg/mL; max 60 mg/kg/day

Behavioral and Mood Management.contraindications: Hepatic disease, pancreatitis, urea cycle disorder, pregnancy (teratogenic), thrombocytopenia
Behavioral and Mood Management.monitoring: Drug level, LFTs, CBC, ammonia, platelets q3-6mo; weight; tremor; alopecia

Behavioral and Mood Management.indication: Aggression, impulsivity, explosive behavior in CTE

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg PO BID; increase by 20 mg/day every 3-5 days; target 40-120 mg/day; max 320 mg/day

Behavioral and Mood Management.contraindications: Asthma, heart block, decompensated HF, severe bradycardia
Behavioral and Mood Management.monitoring: HR, BP; fatigue, depression; bronchospasm; hypoglycemia masking in diabetics

Motor Symptom Management.indication: Parkinsonism (bradykinesia, rigidity, gait impairment) in CTE

dosing.instructions: Start 25/100 mg PO TID; increase by 25/100 mg/dose every 1-2 weeks; target response-based; max 200/2000 mg/day

Motor Symptom Management.contraindications: Concurrent non-selective MAOIs, narrow-angle glaucoma, melanoma (relative)
Motor Symptom Management.monitoring: Dyskinesias; orthostatic hypotension; hallucinations; impulse control; wearing-off

Motor Symptom Management.indication: Parkinsonism with tremor predominance; adjunct to levodopa

dosing.instructions: Start 0.125 mg PO TID; increase by 0.125 mg/dose every 5-7 days; max 1.5 mg TID

Motor Symptom Management.monitoring: Impulse control disorders (gambling, hypersexuality); excessive daytime sleepiness; orthostatic hypotension; hallucinations; renal dose adjustment

Motor Symptom Management.indication: Spasticity, muscle rigidity in advanced CTE

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO TID; increase by 5 mg/dose every 3 days; target 30-80 mg/day; max 80 mg/day

Motor Symptom Management.contraindications: Renal impairment (adjust dose); abrupt withdrawal risk (seizures, hallucinations)
Motor Symptom Management.monitoring: Sedation, weakness; do NOT discontinue abruptly; renal function

Motor Symptom Management.indication: Focal spasticity, dystonia in CTE with motor involvement

dosing.instructions: Dosing by muscle group per specialist; repeat q12 weeks

Motor Symptom Management.contraindications: Infection at injection sites; myasthenia gravis; concurrent aminoglycosides
Motor Symptom Management.monitoring: Spread of toxin effect; local weakness; dysphagia if cervical

Sleep Disturbance Treatment.indication: Insomnia, circadian rhythm disruption in CTE; also REM behavior disorder (RBD)

dosing.instructions: 3-5 mg PO 30-60 minutes before bedtime; may increase to 10 mg for RBD; max 10 mg

Sleep Disturbance Treatment.monitoring: Well tolerated; vivid dreams; morning grogginess

Sleep Disturbance Treatment.indication: Insomnia in CTE (non-habit forming; also reduces agitation)

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg PO QHS; may increase to 100-150 mg QHS; max 200 mg QHS

Sleep Disturbance Treatment.monitoring: Orthostatic hypotension (fall risk); priapism (rare); morning sedation

Sleep Disturbance Treatment.indication: Insomnia in CTE (orexin receptor antagonist; avoids anticholinergic burden)

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg PO QHS; may increase to 20 mg; take within 30 min of bedtime; max 20 mg/day

Sleep Disturbance Treatment.monitoring: Next-day somnolence; sleep paralysis (rare); fall risk

Sleep Disturbance Treatment.indication: REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) with injurious behavior; second-line for insomnia

dosing.instructions: Start 0.25 mg PO QHS; may increase to 0.5-1 mg QHS; use lowest effective dose; avoid long-term if possible

Sleep Disturbance Treatment.contraindications: Severe respiratory depression, severe hepatic impairment, concurrent opioids, obstructive sleep apnea (relative)
Sleep Disturbance Treatment.monitoring: Fall risk; cognitive worsening; respiratory depression; dependence; paradoxical agitation in dementia

Headache Management.indication: Mild-moderate headache in CTE; first-line analgesic (safe in elderly)

dosing.instructions: 500-1000 mg PO q6h PRN; max 3000 mg/day (2000 mg/day if hepatic impairment)

Headache Management.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease, chronic alcohol use
Headache Management.monitoring: LFTs if frequent use; avoid exceeding daily max

Headache Management.indication: Preventive for chronic headache in CTE; also helps insomnia

dosing.instructions: Start 10 mg PO QHS; increase by 10 mg every 1-2 weeks; target 25-75 mg QHS; max 150 mg

Headache Management.contraindications: Cardiac arrhythmia, glaucoma, urinary retention, recent MI; caution in elderly (anticholinergic burden)
Headache Management.monitoring: ECG at baseline; anticholinergic effects (constipation, urinary retention, confusion); weight gain; QTc

Headache Management.indication: Headache prevention (second-line; caution with cognitive side effects in CTE)

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg PO QHS; increase by 25 mg/week; target 50-100 mg BID; max 200 mg/day; USE WITH CAUTION in CTE (cognitive effects)

Headache Management.monitoring: Bicarbonate; COGNITIVE SIDE EFFECTS may worsen CTE cognition (word-finding, processing speed); weight loss; paresthesias

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for TES/CTE diagnostic evaluation, cognitive and behavioral management, and longitudinal monitoring
Neuropsychological testing for objective cognitive assessment, differentiation from other dementias, functional capacity evaluation, and treatment planning
Psychiatry consult for refractory depression, aggression, suicidality, psychosis, or impulse control disorders not responding to first-line treatment
Neuropsychiatry or behavioral neurology for complex cases with overlapping cognitive, behavioral, and motor symptoms requiring integrated management
Physical therapy for gait training, fall prevention, balance rehabilitation, and spasticity management
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation, cognitive compensation strategies, home safety evaluation, and driving assessment
Speech-language pathology for cognitive-linguistic therapy, word-finding, and swallowing evaluation if dysphagia present
Social work for caregiver support, safety planning for patients with aggression, financial planning, advance directives, and community resource coordination
Palliative care consult for advanced CTE with progressive decline to establish goals of care, symptom management, and family support
Sleep medicine referral for refractory insomnia, REM behavior disorder evaluation, or suspected sleep apnea worsening cognition
Endocrinology for suspected post-traumatic hypopituitarism if abnormal pituitary screening labs
Movement disorder specialist if prominent parkinsonian features to optimize dopaminergic therapy and differentiate from PD/DLB
Genetic counseling if APOE testing performed, to discuss implications and family concerns

Patient/Family Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if: new seizure, sudden worsening of confusion, new focal weakness or speech difficulty, fall with head strike, or suicidal ideation (may indicate acute decompensation or comorbid event)
CTE/TES is a clinical diagnosis in living patients; definitive diagnosis currently requires post-mortem neuropathology — ongoing research aims to develop in vivo biomarkers
Avoid all contact sports and activities with high risk of head impact to prevent further repetitive head injury
Avoid alcohol as it worsens cognitive impairment, behavioral disinhibition, and interacts with prescribed medications
Caregiver education on behavioral management: maintain routine, reduce environmental stimulation during agitation, use calm redirection, avoid confrontation
All firearms and weapons must be secured or removed from the home given impulse control deficits and suicide risk
Do not drive unless formally evaluated and cleared by neurology due to cognitive impairment and impulsive behavior increasing accident risk
Establish advance directives and health care proxy early while decision-making capacity is preserved
Take medications consistently at the same time daily; use pill organizers, alarms, or caregiver-assisted medication management
Maintain a symptom and behavior diary to track patterns and treatment response for clinic visits
Report any new symptoms: seizures, personality changes, movement problems, swallowing difficulty, or falls

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Strict avoidance of all repetitive head impacts including contact sports, heading in soccer, and high-risk recreational activities
Cardiovascular risk factor optimization (hypertension, diabetes, hyperlipidemia) to reduce additive cerebrovascular injury
Regular aerobic exercise (30 minutes most days; walking, swimming, stationary bike) to support cardiovascular and brain health
Cognitive engagement: puzzles, reading, social interaction, structured activities to maintain cognitive reserve
Sleep hygiene: consistent bed/wake times, dark quiet cool room, limit screen time before bed, 7-9 hours nightly
Mediterranean-style anti-inflammatory diet rich in omega-3 fatty acids, fruits, vegetables; limit processed foods
Fall prevention: remove home hazards, adequate lighting, grab bars, non-slip mats, assistive device if needed
Smoking cessation to reduce cerebrovascular risk and neuroinflammation
Limit caffeine (<200 mg/day) to reduce anxiety, insomnia, and agitation
Caregiver respite services and support groups (e.g., Concussion Legacy Foundation, Alzheimer Association) to reduce caregiver burnout
Structured daily routine to reduce confusion, agitation, and sundowning behavior

differential.features: Amnestic predominant pattern (encoding deficit); temporoparietal atrophy; positive amyloid biomarkers; typically no RHI history; progressive course without prominent early behavioral features
differential.tests: Amyloid PET (positive in AD); CSF A-beta 42 (low in AD); tau PET pattern (temporoparietal in AD vs sulcal depth in CTE); neuropsych pattern (encoding deficit in AD vs retrieval deficit in CTE)

differential.features: Early personality change, disinhibition, apathy, loss of empathy; frontal atrophy; may lack RHI history; genetic component (C9orf72, MAPT, GRN)
differential.tests: Frontal predominant atrophy on MRI; FDG-PET frontal hypometabolism; genetic testing; negative amyloid PET; no obligate RHI exposure

differential.features: Fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, parkinsonism, RBD; alpha-synuclein pathology; marked neuroleptic sensitivity
differential.tests: DaTscan (abnormal); visual hallucinations early; fluctuating course; REM sleep behavior disorder; extreme sensitivity to antipsychotics

differential.features: Asymmetric resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity; responds to levodopa; typically no RHI history; alpha-synuclein pathology
differential.tests: DaTscan; clinical exam (asymmetric onset, resting tremor); robust levodopa response; no obligate RHI exposure; MIBG cardiac scintigraphy

differential.features: Stepwise decline; vascular risk factors; strategic infarcts or extensive white matter disease; may co-occur with CTE
differential.tests: MRI (lacunar infarcts, extensive WMH, strategic infarcts); vascular risk factor burden; temporal relationship to strokes

differential.features: Classic triad: gait apraxia, urinary incontinence, cognitive decline; ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy
differential.tests: MRI (ventriculomegaly, DESH sign); large-volume LP with gait assessment pre/post; CSF flow study

differential.features: Symptoms within 3 months of specific TBI; typically stable or improving; younger patients; no progressive course
differential.tests: Temporal relationship to single TBI; stable or improving trajectory; no progressive neurodegeneration on serial imaging

differential.features: Mood symptoms predominant; cognitive complaints improve with depression treatment; no progressive course; may lack RHI exposure
differential.tests: PHQ-9; neuropsychological testing before/after antidepressant treatment; no progressive atrophy on serial imaging

differential.features: Chronic heavy alcohol use; nutritional deficiency; may coexist with CTE; frontal/cerebellar atrophy
differential.tests: Alcohol history; thiamine level; MRI (mammillary body atrophy, cerebellar atrophy); improvement with abstinence

differential.features: Cognitive and behavioral symptoms related to active substance use; improvement with sobriety
differential.tests: Urine drug screen; temporal correlation with substance use; improvement with abstinence

differential.features: Episodic mood instability, manic/hypomanic episodes; no progressive cognitive decline; may predate RHI
differential.tests: Psychiatric history; mood charting; episodic rather than progressive course; family history

differential.features: Rapid progressive dementia (weeks to months); myoclonus; periodic sharp waves on EEG; DWI restriction
differential.tests: MRI DWI (cortical ribboning); EEG (periodic sharp waves); CSF RT-QuIC; 14-3-3; rapid course distinguishes

differential.features: Subacute onset; psychiatric features prominent; seizures; may have antibodies
differential.tests: Autoimmune encephalitis panel (serum/CSF); MRI temporal lobe signal changes; EEG; rapid onset

evidence.recommendation: NINDS/NIBIB consensus diagnostic criteria for traumatic encephalopathy syndrome (TES)
Neuropathological criteria for CTE: perivascular p-tau at sulcal depths as pathognomonic lesion
CTE found in 99% of examined NFL players (neuropathological series)
Updated NINDS CTE diagnostic criteria and biomarker framework
Repetitive head impacts as primary risk factor for CTE; dose-response relationship
CSF biomarkers (p-tau 217, NfL) in CTE-related neurodegeneration
Tau PET imaging patterns distinguish CTE from Alzheimer disease
Cholinesterase inhibitors for dementia (applicable to CTE with cognitive impairment)

evidence.source: [McShane R et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/30891742/)

evidence.recommendation: Methylphenidate improves attention and processing speed post-TBI
Amantadine improves cognitive function after TBI
SSRIs for depression in neurodegenerative disease
Black box warning: increased mortality with antipsychotics in elderly dementia patients
Propranolol for aggression in TBI and dementia
evidence.source: [Fleminger S et al. Cochrane Database Syst Rev 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17054218/)
[Tanriverdi F et al. J Clin Endocrinol Metab 2015](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25423570/)

evidence.recommendation: Concussion Legacy Foundation clinical and research resources for CTE families
AAN practice guideline: evaluation and management of concussion

monitoring.action: Adjust cognitive medications; consider additional referrals; functional capacity assessment
Treatment modification; reassess diagnosis; functional capacity evaluation
Immediate psychiatric evaluation if active ideation; safety plan; weapon removal
Adjust behavioral medications; caregiver education; behavioral strategies

monitoring.item: Falls assessment / Timed Up and Go (TUG)
monitoring.action: PT referral; assistive device; home safety evaluation; fall prevention program

monitoring.frequency: q12-24 months or if new symptoms
monitoring.action: If unexpected progression: reassess diagnosis; consider comorbid pathology
Dose adjustment; medication change; simplify regimen; caregiver-assisted dosing

monitoring.frequency: q3-6 months if on mood stabilizers; after dose changes
monitoring.action: Dose adjustment; evaluate adherence; check for drug interactions

monitoring.frequency: q6-12 months; more frequent if on hepatotoxic meds
monitoring.action: Dose adjust or discontinue offending medication; hepatology consult if significant

monitoring.item: Caregiver burden assessment (Zarit Burden Interview or equivalent)
monitoring.action: Respite services; support group referral; social work involvement
Nutrition consult; address medication-related weight changes; swallow evaluation if weight loss
Reduce dose or switch medication; cardiology consult if QTc >500

disposition.criteria: Stable neurologic exam; no acute intracranial pathology on CT; behavioral crisis resolved or manageable; no active suicidality; caregiver able to ensure safety at home; outpatient follow-up arranged; safety precautions reviewed

New or worsening cognitive decline requiring inpatient evaluation; behavioral disturbance not safely managed at home; fall with neurologic concern; new seizure requiring observation; dehydration or medication toxicity; caregiver unable to ensure safety

Status epilepticus; severe behavioral disturbance requiring continuous monitoring and parenteral sedation; aspiration pneumonia with respiratory compromise; traumatic intracranial hemorrhage (subdural hematoma from fall); hemodynamic instability

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for specialized neuroimaging (PET, research MRI protocols) not available; neurosurgical evaluation for subdural hematoma; specialized CTE/TES research center evaluation
Initial: 4-6 weeks after diagnosis or medication initiation; then q3-6 months for stable patients; more frequently during medication titration; neuropsychological testing annually
Progressive decline with inability to perform ADLs safely; caregiver unable to manage behavioral symptoms; wandering risk; medication non-adherence despite interventions; recurrent falls
Advanced CTE with progressive decline; dysphagia with aspiration risk; bedbound; family goals aligned with comfort-focused care
